Train 'til you sweat. Train to become stronger. Train towards victory and fly all the way to the top of the powerhouses! With a jump and a hit that gets past the blockers, Season 2 of Haikyuu!! wondered the crowd with a new exciting entertainment.
Continuing where Season 1 left off, the black and orange team that we all came to love returned back, boasting a determination ever stronger than before. This season is packed with all the training and practice goodness that they needed in order to survive against the skilled opponents in their journey.A handful of new characters were introduced too, but this did presented some issues that affected the plot. While we were treated with backstories that expanded on the characters, the amount and timing disrupted the suspense that were generated, essentially losing that buildup that hyped you up. It canceled each other out so it's kind of a win-lose situation where a bit too much of one thing slightly ruined the other factor. Another minor gripe I had was the repetition of volleyball plays in a few episodes to the point where it can be boring. But they didn't drew me away from the interactions between the characters. Their realistic approach to winning and losing was a refresher, leading to great development of themselves. Like before, no one was really left out, having their own fair go being in the spotlight of inspiration. It was awesome seeing how each team has their own unique playstyle, and the matches to prove how much improvements they made over the months to be in the court with opponents led to new tricks, trusts and teamworks that awed an nonathletic person like me. And the comedy. There weren't as much as before but the ones that did appeared got me chuckled.\n\n
For the art style, Haikyuu!! have this unique way of visualization where it contained a lot more lines in their design, particularly in the shadows or during fast moments. It's not particularly flashy or special but the simplicity perfectly fitted the characters and volleyball actions. One other related thing I've noticed during the course of this season was in the expressions of the characters. Their eyes evoked a lot of strong feelings, looking intently at the ball during moments of high concentration. You just know that they won't let that ball touch the ground, making them so much more impressive in the court. The animation was pretty fluid at most times, however, there were scenes where it looked sluggish and failed to delivered the energy from the athleticism of the characters. Those times made them looked quite lazy in fact, which was contrary to what they are as volleyball players. Thankfully, the slow-mo scenes were breathtaking to watch and was as splendid as ever showing off the shots. And for the sounds, the opening and ending themes were pleasant to hear. I'm not sure how to explain it but they have this underlying atmosphere that captured the moral of 'training to become stronger'. As usual, each soundtracks, especially the epic ones, were composed beautifully to go along with their respective moments. Amplifying the 'oomph' of a powerful shot or conveying the disappointment and regrets from losing, the OSTs did a wonderful job. The second season of the smash-hit sports anime, Haikyuu!! S2 continues the trend of greatness set forth by its predecessor. With stronger character development, a solid (but predictable) plot, various stellar songs, and consistent art, I can see why this is so highly rated on MAL.
[Story - 7]
This season follows the Karasuno team's efforts to grow stronger and make a comeback after suffering a narrow defeat at the hands of Aoba Johsai. The first half follows their rigorous training program, both at their own gym and at the 2 training camp sessions hosted by rival schools, and the second half follows their effortsin the Spring High Preliminaries. 


Thanks to the hook of the finale for last season, the first half of S2 starts out strong and definitely provides entertainment in both drama and comedy. The latter half, however, is....not that strong. Perhaps it's due to the inevitable plot armour around Karasuno, but it doesn't really surprise anyone. The moments of drama aren't really /that/ dramatic if you're genre-savvy, but they do provide a nice break from the constant tension in each game. I still enjoyed this half nonetheless thanks to the pay-off from the first half, but your mileage will vary, of course.


[Art - 7]


The art hasn't really improved, but neither has it dropped in quality. There's still a lot of consistently strong character design (especially in regards to new characters such as 'Mad Dog' and Bokuto), but some animations are DEFINITELY still being re-used. That being said, I've also noted that they introduced a multitude of new ones, so I'm pleased to see that at least they put more effort there.


[Sound - 9]


The SFX haven't changed as well (naturally), save for some new additions to complement new moves. Still pretty solid here.


The seiyuus keep up the good work, as is expected. Shout-out goes to Yamaguchi's, Yachi's, and Chikara's for injecting TONS of emotion into their characters when given the chance. 


The soundtrack has somehow gotten even better: While there are songs from last season that appear, there are even MORE songs now!!! Probably expected by everyone else, but I was so happy to hear them play. The new OPs and EDs are AMAZING, especially for the second half. 


[Character - 8]


Characterization has definitely gotten better this time around! Thanks to the developments from both the S1 finale and the first half of S2, everyone on Karasuno goes through some type of development arc that is rather satisfying to see. My personal favourite was Tsukishima's, as he went from someone who was...Just There for snarkiness to a well-rounded character/player that shows considerable promise. Another arc to note is Yamaguchi's, as we get to see how he handles his failures and grows from them to become a valuable pinch server to the team. All in all, everyone on the Karasuno team got really good writing, and the ending they got for this season felt well-earned.


Other characters, however, may not be so fortunate. Since there were multiple schools introduced in the Training and SHP arcs, of course some underdevelopment happened. But like last time, there were a few surprises: Hitoka Yachi, the new Karasuno VBC Manager, brings the cuteness AND gets a small arc dedicated to her; Johzenji High School goes through the challenge of finally figuring out a good playstyle; and Tooru Oikawa has to bring out his best to face his rival, Kageyama, on equal ground. Some characters still remain underdeveloped, like the other staff behind the Karasuno VBC and ace spiker Ushijima, but again, perhaps next season will bring them their due development.


One other notable flaw, however, is melodrama. It was expected, since this IS a sports anime, but.....come on. It just gets really ridiculous sometimes. I hope they tone it down in S3. 


[Enjoyment/Overall - 9/8]


Overall, this second season was a BLAST to experience. It was so much fun to revisit the growing pains of Karasuno, and the beginnings of their labour bearing fruit, along with seeing the many new faces introduced throughout these arcs. If you loved the first season, you'll definitely love this season!

Continuing the flow from my review on Haikyuu!!... I'd say that this season picks up really well from where the first season left off. Similar to how I started that review I'd say this season is where the flock of crows start to work themselves into that "polished diamond" that they never were in the first place. 
Admittedly I don't think they got there in this season either but I'll be damned if there wasn't a lot of improvements and new "tricks" added that they "borrow" from some of the other schools that were in the intensive training camp.
I like to think of this seasonas being pretty much split in two and I liked the way it was done. For the vast majority of the first half of the season we see Karasuno being whipped into shape in the gym. As that's happening we do actually get to see some individual character development both inside and outside the gym. I personally think they did well with it overall. We even got to see small bits into Nekoma and Fukurodani. Some of the best comedy of the season came from little scenes involving a mix of players from either of the teams which I appreciated.


The first half of the season comes to a conclusion pretty much with the ending of the training camp and if the lack of intensity gets to you then rest assured there's enough in the last half to satisfy and then some.


I honestly liked all of the games in the second half of this season a ton. I think a big reason why I can say that is that I didn't forget one big thing here... There is the SHOUNEN tag attached to this Anime along with Sports and Comedy. There are some things that we just have to take along with us for the ride because it is also a shounen... I also happen to think they do more than a good job going into the thoughts of the players during the matches while the ball is in motion or there is a stop in play momentarily. I think I can enjoy that aspect of this franchise because while it might not always be realistic, that's okay! This is a work of fiction, some stuff can be exaggerated. While it might be a little over the top sometimes, even though I've never played volleyball in my life, I can really imagine an actual person thinking some of that stuff to himself in mid rally that they do.


I thought the soundtrack to this Anime was great and shockingly enough it was the second season when I really started to notice. I didnt even realize they used quite a few tracks over from the first season in the second season. The only reason I noticed at all was because of my re-watch of the franchise. The way they used snippets of a lot of the tracks in the volleyball games during the second half really brought everything out I think. Which is why I really latched onto the music in the second season and not the first.


I believe this was a fine continuation of the franchise. I still think this a worthwhile franchise for anyone to watch as an introduction to the sports genre. If you can take some stuff with a grain of salt I think youll end up loving it.
